page.title: 07 Coppicing (2)
page.content: The cutting season lasts from November to March (or May at the latest).Only the straight lengths can be used for fencing.The rest, poor quality known as 'rough wood', is sent to Chartham Paper Mills for pulp for paper making.The woodcutters rely on cutting rough wood in the summer.The men take the lengths of chestnut back to their yard.They are then put into bundles of 25 palings and wired together by special machines to sell to firms in Scotland, Nottingham and Kent.Much of it is sent back to Kent for use as snow fencing on the side of motorways and highways.The men used a chainsaw and a saw bolted on to the front of their old tractor and driven off the tractor engine.The tractor can also be used for transporting the lengths out of inaccessible areas of the wood to waiting trucks.
